questions.text: What is the most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries is rheumatic fever. This is mainly due to the repeated infections with rheumatogenic streptococci and inadequate coverage of antibiotics. It mainly affects the mitral valve.

In developed countries, degenerative or inflammatory processes are the most common cause of valvular heart diseases.

questions.text: What is the normal range for the mitral valve area in an adult?
questions.solution:
The size of the mitral orifice in a normal adult is 4-6 sq cm. 

Depending on the area of mitral valve opening (MVA), mitral stenosis can be classified as:

  • Progressive MS - MVA > 1.5 sq cm
  • Severe MS - MVA ≤ 1.5 sq cm
  • Very severe MS - ≤ 1 sq cm

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle hypertrophy is seen.

Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS):

In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle.

When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these conditions:

  •  Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA pressure
  •  Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output

The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

questions.solution:
Mid-systolic click is least likely to be heard in a patient with mitral stenosis. It is seen in a patient with mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital in view of severe dyspnea. History revealed that the dyspnea was exertional initially and later worsened to breathlessness during normal daily activities. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The image of the autopsy of the heart is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution: The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with breathlessness for 5 months. She is unable to carry out her daily activities and has difficulty sleeping. On examination, she has a parasternal heave. On auscultation, opening snap (OS) is heard followed by a low pitched rumbling diastolic murmur. Which of the following findings is suggestive of increased severity of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis. The more severe the thickening, the earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, the decreased interval between A2 and opening snap (OS) indicates increased severity of the stenosis.

The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are:

  • Decreased interval between A2 and OS
  • Increased duration of the diastolic murmur

Loud S1 is seen in the initial stages of MS when the mitral leaflets are flexible. When there is further thickening and calcification of the leaflets, they become immobile, and the amplitude of S1 decreases.

Increased severity of the stenosis increases the left atrial pressure. This increase in left atrial pressure can increase pulmonary artery pressure which leads to loud P2 on auscultation.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac chambers is enlarged in mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
questions.solution:
Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views.

Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema.

Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.

questions.text: A patient with mitral stenosis presented with worsening dyspnea and fatigue which are now present at rest. He also complained of a feeling of heavy pounding in the chest with recurrent chest pain. You decided to evaluate the patient using echocardiography. When would you advise the patient to undergo a valvotomy?

choices.text: In all patients who are symptomatic

questions.solution:
Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral stenosis (MS) with orifice < 1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area.

Treatment of mitral stenosis:

  • Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation.
  • Surgical treatment includes:
    • Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy.
    • Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for panic disorder was referred to the physician for complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. Detailed history revealed the presence of chest pain, which was substernal and not related to exercise. On auscultation, mid-systolic clicks were audible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse.

It is caused due to the myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. It may be associated with Marfan's syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. It is more common in females of the age group of 15- 30 years.

Most patients are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with symptoms such as palpitations, syncope due to arrhythmias (premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation), non-specific chest pain, and dyspnea

Auscultation reveals mid-systolic clicks. If there is associated mitral regurgitation, a systolic murmur might also be heard. The duration of the murmur of MVP decreases on squatting and increases on standing. Whereas the duration of the murmur of MR increases on squatting and decreases on standing.

questions.text: Carvallo’s sign is associated with the murmur of which valvulopathy?
questions.solution:
Carvallo’s sign refers to the increase in the intensity of systolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation with inspiration.

During inspiration, the venous return to the heart increases due to the negative intrathoracic pressure. This increases the leak from the right ventricle to the right atrium making the murmur louder.

In general, the right-sided heart murmurs increase in intensity with inspiration and decrease in intensity with expiration, while the opposite is true for left-sided heart murmurs. Pulmonic ejection sound is the only right-sided acoustic event that decreases in intensity with inspiration.

questions.text: The severity of mitral regurgitation can be assessed by:
questions.solution:
The severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be assessed by the wide splitting of the S2. Due to severe regurgitation of blood, the pressure in the left ventricle falls rapidly, leading to the early closure of the aortic valve. 

Clinical findings that indicate the severity of MR is:

  • Reduced cardiac output
  • Palpable systolic thrill
  • Palpable S3
  • Wide splitting of S2

Note: The intensity of murmur does not always correlate with the severity of the murmur. Intensity may be diminished in severe MR caused by LV dysfunction, acute MI and periprosthetic valve regugitation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are:

  1. Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to the left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
  2. Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery.
  3. Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

questions.text: A patient presented with breathlessness on exertion and chest pain. Auscultation revealed an ejection systolic murmur heard best at the base of the heart. Echocardiography showed reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following features does not signify a severe form of this disease?
questions.solution:
The above features point to a diagnosis of aortic stenosis. Wide splitting of S2 is not a feature of severe aortic stenosis. On the contrary, there might be single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2.

Features of severe aortic stenosis are:

  • Pulsus parvus et tardus
  • Palpable carotid thrill
  • Louder and late peaking of systolic murmur
  • Single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2
  • Presence of S3 and S4 heart sounds
  • Signs of right and left ventricular failure
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Acute myocardial infarction is not associated with aortic regurgitation.

Aortic regurgitation is the backflow of the blood from the aorta to the left ventricle.

It may be caused either due to the defect in the valve or defect in the aortic root (dilation of the aortic annulus).

Conditions that affect valves are:

  • Congenital
  • Endocarditis
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Myxomatous (prolapse)
  • Traumatic
  • Syphilis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

Conditions that affect aortic root are:

  • Aortic dissection
  • Cystic medial degeneration
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Bicuspid aortic valve
  • Hypertension

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. On examination, a diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space and pistol shot sound is heard over the femoral arteries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a diastolic murmur along with the pistol shot sound over the femoral is most likely to be due to aortic regurgitation.

The image below explains the mechanism of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with exertional dyspnea and angina. On examination, the pulse was characterized by abrupt distention and quick collapse. Auscultation revealed an early diastolic murmur. Which of the following is a feature of this murmur with respect to the likely diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Severity correlates with intensity of murmur

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of aortic regurgitation. An early diastolic murmur is a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler echocardiography?
questions.solution:
Regurgitant volume >60mL/ beat is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler echocardiography (TTE).

Doppler echocardiography can be used to assess the severity of aortic regurgitation. According to this, AR is considered to be severe when:

  • Central jet width is more than 65% of left ventricular outflow tract
  • Vena contracta width >6mm
  • Regurgitant fraction >50%
  • Regurgitant volume >60mL/beat
  • Effective regurgitant orifice >0.3cm2

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement (AVR).

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery (AVR) is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic.
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

questions.text: A patient has enlarged neck veins, hepatomegaly and a holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is tricuspid regurgitation.

Clinical features of tricuspid regurgitation are:

  • Distended neck veins with prominent c-v waves
  • Hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations
  • Positive hepatojugular reflex - the distension of the jugular vein when firm pressure is applied over the liver
  • Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin

questions.text:
On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
  1. Mitral regurgitation
  2. Tricuspid stenosis
  3. Mitral stenosis
  4. Tricuspid regurgitation
  5. Atrial septal defect
questions.solution: The given phonocardiogram is of a pansystolic/holosystolic murmur. It is heard in mitral regurgitation (MR), tricuspid regurgitation (TR), and ventricular septal defect (VSD).

questions.text: A patient has a right upper limb BP of 180/95 mm Hg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mm Hg. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
A significant difference in blood pressure measured between two arms (>10 mm Hg) may be seen in Takayasu arteritis (subclavian artery disease), supravalvular aortic stenosis, aortic coarctation, and aortic dissection (all four options).

An early diastolic murmur in the right second intercostal space (aortic area) is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option A), which involves the part of the aorta distal to the aortic valve, is unlikely to cause aortic regurgitation and hence the best answer.

Features  Supravalvular AS Takayasu arteritis Aortic dissection Coarctation of aorta
Aortic regurgitation Unlikely Present in 25% of cases Present in acute situations Present
BP difference between arms Present Present Present May be present

So the single best answer would be Supravalvular AS > Coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: Barlow’s syndrome refers to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Barlow’s syndrome refers to mitral valve prolapse.

Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is also called as systolic click-murmur syndrome, Barlow’s syndrome or floppy valve syndrome. It is the most common abnormality leading to primary mitral regurgitation.

Note: Infantile scurvy is referred to as Barlow's disease.
